Hey this game is great.  I haven't had this much fun in a side scrolling beat em' up in ages.  Now, for the muliplayer review:\n\nWhoever designed the co-op mode's connection system is an idiot of the highest order and I hope he or she has to suffer trying to play this hunk of garbage as Player 2 for eternity.  I bought the game for my friend even though I'm tight on cash right now since I'm moving, thinking it would be worth it.  Guess what?  It isn't.  All the fun I expected to have with my bro will probably never happen because I'm experiencing the worst lag I think I've ever experienced since I began PC gaming circa 1999.  Trying to revive him is a nightmare and he usually ends up dying because while trying to position myself over his corpse, I take three or four extra steps and end up elsewhere.  For a game series that has always relied on skill and timing and made you feel accomplished when you could get through the games with only one or two lives lost (or as is my personal case with Super Double Dragon IV for the SNES, zero lives lost - try it, it's fun!), this was a real downer.  Again, I recommend this game fully for its single player mode.  Great 80's feel, awesome music, and just the right amount of grinding to become powerful.... but if you happen to be reading this and you're planning on paying good money for the co-op mode, don't bother.  Contrary to at least one article out there, the player 2 lag-a-thon has NOT been fixed.

I've played the online coop mode with a friend of mine and we certainly had a lot of fun. Although it's hard to compare this newest game with some of the classic beat'em up arcade versions (or even with the unique Streets of Rage), Neon surely has a charm of its own. As for the inevitable comparisons with the former games of the franchise, I'd just say that the OST from back then is still superior and despite the wacky story of this title, nothing can be as bad as Double Dragon 3. We've came across an annoying glitch during our gameplay, but overall we had a positive experience. If you enjoy kicking some butts, then go for it.
High flying, bad guys dying, and best friends high fiving. Man, this game has it all. With amazing gameplay, music, and artwork for all players to enjoy.

I write this for those who are looking for a co-op game to play with their young child (age ~6+). This may well be the game for you.

I'm godfather to a 6-y/o boy. He loves games, and so do I, but there aren't that many games that we can play *together*. And there are fewer games still that hit that sweet spot. For example, he likes to play Metal Slug with me, but has trouble with the platforming elements (very minor in this game), and there generally isn't much I can do for him when we play, other than kill all the enemies quickly. The ideal game is one where I can help him out but he still feels like he's pulling his weight. And that's exactly where this game had us. With me playing just a little better than average, the two of us were able to finish the game together. You can share health and life points in fun but easy ways (in-game high-fives, he loves it). You can forgo taking any of the power-ups yourself. You can choose 1 special move (which you can then power up using in-game money, which is also shareable) and you can also choose 1 passive buff. In that way, you can find a combination that makes up for your kid's weaknesses. Give him extra health and defense, or an invulnerable spin kick. We had a lot of success with the combination of magic gambit (extra magic power) and the dragon swarm, which makes a giant dragon appear on the screen and hits all the enemies no matter what (but takes up a lot of magic power, hence the magic gambit) special. He loved doing this. We finished the game together on normal mode, and went a good distance into hard mode already.

If you want to have a good time playing with a young one that has a decent understanding of how different buttons consistently produce different actions, then this could be the game for you. I do recommend buying it during a sale, as I think it is worth closer to $7.5 than it is to $15. The pc version has crashed on me a few times during the final boss battle and ending scene, but that may have been caused by the latest nvidia driver, which was giving me some other problems as well. Seems resolved now.

Fantastic Beat 'em up with a lot of awesome aesthetics.
It knows what it wants to be and it's hard not to get hooked in with the silliness of the humor, references and the music.
The music, by the way, is REALLY good, as per usual with Wayforward games.

The fighting mechanics are simple but great. It's not at all a button masher, which is something a lot of beat 'em ups unfortunately end up being.
Every move feels like it matters as you need to time your heavy attacks just right and dodge at the right time to increase your damage output.
Mashing the attack buttons will just get you killed quicker basically.
So the fighting mechanics are very welcomed as it feels very satisfying now that it's more difficult for all the right reasons... Well almost all.
See, this game also introduces very light RPG elements. You collect two types of music tapes: Special moves and Stances. The latter is what kinda rubs me the wrong way.
It undermines the importance of skill when fighting. If you have too few tapes of one stance, it's not worth it on the harder difficulties. Too many and it's a bit too easy.
I like the tape collecting, but I wish that stances wasn't a thing. Or at least that they wouldn't increase or decrease stats with more tapes like like the special moves.
It's not that bad, but it's a slight annoyance when you realize that getting 10 more tapes for Balance" made the harder difficulties much easier.

In conclusion: Awesome game which I think is the best in the series. Even if you're not a fan of Double Dragon

reviewText: Game is good unfortunately its riddled with issues. I am using windows 10 and game crashes after 30 mins of gameplay. I tried multiple fixes but no use. I would recommend not to waste money on this till the time the issue is fixed.

As a fan of Double Dragon Neon on consoles, I was excited to learn that a port of the game existed on Steam. The quality of the port, done by Abstraction Games, and published by Midnight City, is mixed at best and this will be the focus of my review. For a review of the story and gameplay, I recommend checking out other reviewers.

For one, I played the game primarily using the online multiplayer portion of the game. I can tell you that, having played the game on separate occasions and even perusing through the discussion boards here on Steam, that the port is plagued by constant crashes and progression breaks. One such example occurs during Mission 9, after Player 2 successfully completes the first area of the mission, the next area refused to load because Player 1 was dead. Crashes were commonplace and would trigger randomly throughout our playthrough. Much of my game time indicated on my account is just restarting the game over and attempting to reconnect to the host. The network code, at best, also doesn't hold up to current standards as it is prone to random lag and affects the frame rate dramatically at times. Publisher support has been little to none, which is sad because the game itself was solid on consoles.

I highly recommend picking up the console versions over this one, unless you're planning to reverse engineer the game and spend time fixing the issues I've outlined for the community.

The game itself is great.  However, with windows 10, it crashes randomly, even with suggested fixes given by users.\n\nDo NOT get ripped off by Steam selling this broken game (on windows 10) until a permenant fix is made.  Steam is selling you a defective product!

Where to start?  Double Dragon Neon is a reboot of the Double Dragon series.  It is artisically sound and the gameplay is a lot more larger than the older versions.  Never once did I feel that it wasn't a part of the franchise.  To me it felt like how a modern Double Dragon should be.  I give this a thumbs up for most everything involved from storyline to the 80s cinematic cheese they presented in with the neat little package of added features like songs(powerups) and the small variance on the classic Double Dragon arcade side-scrolling beat em' ups.  The negatives I noticed where small but do matter:  Multiplayer online seems to be a ghost town and I had to configure the .ini file to get the controller on player 1 working correctly.  Is there life left in this puppy?  I definitely think so and if you catch it on sale it is definitely worth the pickup.

What really is there I can say about the game when it's hard just to fully enjoy the game?

I'm writing this from a Win7 Machine, don't even attempt to play on a win 10 machine.

the possitives: good controls, good music, and good visuals. It is a fun solid game as it starts for those first 5 levels...

The Negative: WHEN it freezes it does it so hard I had to restart my computer. You can't just shut off Steam or turn it off on the task bar, stream waits for the game to shut down (which it never does) before closing, and with the task bar option Steam keeps it running. This happened to me on levels 6, and 9, levels with falling arrows very much don't like it when the falling arrows hit something. The community has found a work around for this problem. You'll have to open your task manager and right click on the game > set affinity and set it to only run on 1 core, this should fix it. Thanks to the community, seeing how the dev team knew about this for quite a while with zero feedback on fixing it.

Risk it if you want, it is a fun and solid game when it works, try applying the work around if you hit the freezing problem. You will have to do it after restarting the game but it might be the help you need. Also remember it's pretty much unplayable on a win 10 machine, wish I could also say something about win8 but I don't have an 8 box.

This  game is simultaneously a reboot of an arcade classic and a clever pastiche of 1980s pop culture.  The art style, music, and other elements are heavily inspired by the decade that brought us the original game.  One special move called the Bro-Dozer" has a theme tune reminiscent of Kylie Minogue's cover of "The Locomotion".  The voice of the game's main villain closely resembles that of Skeletor from Filmation's animated MASTERS OF THE UNIVERSE series.  The game even pokes fun at the concept of the "load-bearing boss".\n\nNostalgia aside
recommended: if a bit challenging.  Special moves and abilities can be acquired by collecting "mixtapes" (another nod to 80s music culture).  Collecting extras of a given tape increase the power of that special move/ability.  After several plays
hoursPlayed: you'll become powerful enough to beat the first boss and collect chunks of "Mithril"
voteText: an ore that allows further upgrades of mixtape abilities.  This means that a little bit of backtracking and level grinding is needed to power up enough to survive the final battle.   Given the low price of the game and the humorous trip down memory lane it provides

I've played this game upwards of 72 hours despite what my account suggests. My initial experience to the game was that it felt slow but what can you do? It's not exactly a traditional sprite based beat'em up with attack wind ups to make the attacks look smoother. Actually, the speed is appropriate for some of the gameplay mechanics to function properly (gleam).

Initially, in the first difficulty setting you may not understand the game fully even with the in game tutorials. DDN encourages crouching an avoidable attack to gain attack bonuses so that you can take out enemies more efficiently. You'll undoubtedly acquire mixtapes from enemies to either have stat bonuses or a special attack that uses up meter. You'll get to have 2 tapes on max (one special attack and one stats booster).

By the time I reached the later difficulties my experience when playing the game was at its max. My character's stats were appropriate to the difficulty and the game became fair and less frustrating. It's up to you to get good at the game and enjoy its quirky 80's aesthetics. If anyone is further interested in the gameplay mechanics feel free to youtube Episode 24 of my Beat'em up Dissection" videos."

column16: June 4
column17: true

reviewText: I view this masterpiece through a shattered lens. I am a modern man, currently up to the standards with the Master Race, and have Windows 10 with DirectX 12, with an Nvidia card. Thus, this game crashes constantly. The publisher, Majesco, is a hair's breadth from death, and I don't believe any of their five remaining employees are working on fixing this game. Furthermore, I have it on good authority that Gabe Newell is in league with Skullmageddon himself, which would explain why my 99¢ refund has been denied. That, or my request was months beyond the 2-week expiration.

Product received for free

The presentation, the music, the levels are all top notch. But everything else, not so much.

A beat-em-up doesn't really need rpg elements, you just want to beat people up not wanting to upgrade skills all time. The combat also feels lackluster, grabs have no depth to them the original Double Dragon had more depth to the fighting. The counter move feels unnecessary, since it usually backfires getting punched by someone else instantly.

The humour feels forced, someone along the lines belong more in a Ninja Turtles game since the other Double Dragon games were dark in nature.

Online co-op doesn't work it's a laggy mess, fights feel more like your ice skating.

You can upgrade your skills, but after playing it once you won't feel like touching it again.

Maybe for a $1 when it's on sale, if you're itching for a beat-em-up. Otherwise don't bother with this one.
